items.name: React
items.description:
React has changed a lot over the years since I started to learn it in 2017. From class components to function components, and now server components and even a compiler. It's been cool to see it continue to develop and keep up with the development.

It's definitely my go-to framwork if I'm going to build a front-end and I've used it for several of my hobby projects. I also used it while I was working on a contract basis for my friend since the main tracking website was built with React and I sometimes had to implement new features or re-factor

items.name: TypeScript
items.description: TypeScript was one of the things I stayed away from for the longest time because I didn't really feel like I needed it. But I guess after getting into typed languages such a Golang and C# I started to see the value in it. And after one too many 'cannot read property of undefined' errors I decided to pick up TypeScript and used it for my Kombucha Brewery project. I think it's especially good when you can get that full stack end-to-end type safety.

items.name: Node.js
items.description: Node.js is probably where I feel the most comfortable and have the most coding experience. I really like how fast you can build something and the flexibility of it, as well as the enourmous amount of tooling available.

items.name: Go
items.description: Go is the first typed and compiled language I learned. And I think it's a perfect first pick. It's really simple but yet powerful. And I love that basically everything you need is included in the standard library. I do think it can get a bit overly verbose sometimes tho. The concurrency model is awesome.

items.name: Microsoft SQL Server
items.description: I used to be a Postgres and SQlite dude, but after being forced to work so much in SQL server at my current job, I actually really started to like it. I dig all the functionality in SSMS and keep finding new stuff in there all the time. I utilize stored procedures a lot, but also functions and triggers.

items.name: Postgres
items.description: Great open source database when you need a bit more features than SQlite. I used it for several of my hobby projects such as Top XYZ and Kombucha Brewery.

items.name: Git
items.description: Git is such a core skill as a software developer, and I'm happy I started using it from the very beginning of my programming journey.

items.name: AI assisted programming
items.description: I'm consistently trying to stay at the forefront of new technology. Keeping up with new AI developments is no easy task as new models and tools keep popping up. Recently I started to use Cursor as my main editor, and I'm very impressed by the Claude 3.5 Sonnet model. I don't think AI will replace programmers, but I do think hand writing code professionally will eventually become a thing of the past, unless it's done as a hobby. Just as blacksmithing or other professions of the past has changed, programmers will need to evolve.

items.name: Linux
items.description: Linux is an amazing development environment as it's free, open-source, stable, secure, customizable and extremely powerful with great developer tooling. Even though there are many different distibutions of Linux I've so far only used the debian based Ubuntu.

items.name: HTML
items.description:
HTML is the corner stone of the world wide web. It is used to organize and categorize the content of a website.

I have been using HTML since 2017 and I feel very comfortable using it.

items.name: CSS
items.description:
CSS is the paint brush for the web.

I rarely use vanilla CSS these days as I prefer tailwind where I can use pre defined classes to get stuff done quicker.
